stories.text:
Hey all, I need some advice.

I'm 25 yo.

I've a master degree in cognitive science, during my studies I really enjoyed statistics. I also had a programming course.

Lately I've enrolled for weekend school for Data Visualisation. Where I learn Jupyter notebooks, pandas, matplotlib etc.

I live in Europe, my parents are stuck in Ukraine and I need to start working asap.

- How would you suggest going about internship / junior position? I still feel like I'm not good enough to work.

- Any Data science blogs / job boards that I should follow?

- What makes sense in the portfolio? Some homemade projects in Jupiter / kaggle? Does is make sense to link them to cv?

thanks
stories.title: Cognitive Science to Data Scientist?

stories.text:
Hi HN!

I am looking to buy a laptop for software development in the 0 to $2000 (USD) range.

What I am looking for: 1. Durability: battery life is important to me as well as general longevity of the hardware i.e. I would like it to last a long time.

2. Linux support: I use Linux as my OS of choice and I have no intention of using Windows/MacOS

3. Optimized for intensive computing usage.

Other things of note:

I looked into the Framework laptops and so far it looks like they are still a bit beta.

However, I am curious about users' experiences with:

* the KDE Slimbook 15: https://slimbook.es/en/store/slimbook-kde/kde-slimbook-15-comprar

* the Purism Librem 14: https://puri.sm/products/librem-14/

* Kubuntu Focus: https://kfocus.org/order/order-m2.html

* the StarBook 14-inch – Star Labs®: https://starlabs.systems/pages/starbook

Also tips about maintaining battery life would be appreciated. I've read too much conflicting advice about that lately :) Thanks.
stories.title: Ask HN: What's a good laptop for software development in –$2000 range
Analyst suggests the iPhone 14 will have an autofocus front camera
Unable to focus on programming around 3-4 PM every day. How can I fix this?
